Award.AwardTitle: Strain-Activated Signaling within Cell Adhesions Dictates Cell Fate

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Just like steel girders hold up buildings, extracellular matrix fibers help hold tissues together. Cells within tissues act like people in buildings: they adhere to and crawl on extracellular matrix like people walk on the floors. Unlike people however, cells also pull against their matrix and can respond to the stiffness of this adjacent matrix. Normally, stem cells respond simply by maturing into the cells already present in the tissue. However diseases often cause these fibers to become stiffer than normal, which makes the stem cells within these tissues respond inappropriately; cells that typically become muscle instead mature into bone. While we have made such observations, our understanding of why this occurs is limited. Thus a systematic examination of how physical cues like stiffness are converted into biochemical cues that a stem cell can interpret is greatly needed. One of the ways that cells can sense the stiffness of the tissues that surround them is through the unfolding of particular molecules from the forces of cellular contraction. Using computer analysis of known protein structures, the investigator has identified two strong candidates for molecules that will unfold and allow the cells to measure force. Cell chemical pathways identified through this study could be targeted in genetic therapies to treat diseases that stiffen tissues such as cancer and heart disease.

Cells sense extracellular matrix properties by contracting against it and converting that information into biochemical readouts in a process called mechanotransduction. Despite understanding the inputs and outputs of this process, little is known about mechanically induced signaling that occurs in between these observations. Stem cells are ideally suited to elucidate these molecular details because they present a "blank slate" where maturation into specific tissues can describe the sensitivity of a physical-to-chemical sensor, i.e. fat cells are less contractile than muscle and bone cells. This research will combine current molecular tools and engineering approaches to test whether proteins within a cell adhesion act as a "molecular strain gauge," i.e. it exposes cryptic kinase binding sites under strain. A bioinformatics-based screen has identified 3 proteins with cryptic kinase binding sites, e.g. SORBS1, SORBS3, and vinculin; project objectives will use in situ fluorescence resonance energy transfer assays to describe cellular strain-induced conformational changes in these proteins and validate the "molecular strain gauge" model for signaling. It will also confirm the function of new mechanosensors, which could be used as therapeutic targets to make stem cells insensitive to tissue stiffening.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The environment that surrounds cells is full tissue that range from soft fat to hard bones. For adult stem cells that show up in these tissues after they've been formed, it is clear that the tissue helps tell these cells what to do. While most biologists and engineers assumed that well known biochemical signals told these stem cells to become fat or bone, an emerging area of research showed that how soft or stiff the tissue was also programmed adult stem cells to become fat or bone or any soft of tissue in between. However, we did not appreciate HOW such a mechanical signal communicated its information to the stem cell and how the stem cell then knew to become fat, bone, or other mature cells. This work developed a high throughput tool that where many small interfering RNA (siRNA) molecules could be studied in parallel for their ability to block an adult stem cell from sensing how soft or stiff their environment is. Without this information, the adult stem cell would sit in the dish but never become fat or bone. Each siRNA blocked a specific gene/protein, so when any given siRNA prevented the adult stem cell from becoming a mature cell, it was identified as possibly playing a role in converting the mechanical signal of soft/stiff into a biochemical signal that the stem cell could recognize. These candidates identified in this screen as possible "strain gauge" proteins (named for a common sensor that measures the amount a material has been stretched) were validated using 2 complex methods that measure the stretch of the environment outside and inside the cell, i.e. traction force microscopy (TFM) and flourescent resonance energy transfer (FRET), respectively. Of the dozens of candidates that were predicted computationally, 3 showed possible sensing properties. Upon validation, we confirmed that Vinculin is a mechanical sensor that detects strain and converts that signal into a chemical response that causes adult stem cells to become muscle-like. The intellectual merit of this work lies in this new pipeline of how to detect such mechanisms in stem cells, the high throughput screen itself, and the protein identified as a sensor, i.e. Vinculin. The broader impact of this work was to expand our understanding of these sensors, how they work, and their use in stem cells. Additionally, graduate student training, and K-12 activities to show students what stem cells are, both in classrooms at a charter school in San Diego and at the San Diego Science and Engineering EXPO, provide community impact.
